Chinatown.name: Chinatown
reviews:
When visiting a new city I always check out their Chinatown area and this is one of the best. The area is very colorful, with the beautiful store facades and the lanterns hanging overhead. There are many, many shops and restaurants to choose from, and alleys to explore. If visiting, I highly recommend doing the Fortune Cookie Factory and the Golden Gate Bakery and try one of their popular Egg Custards...
Show less
Very cool authentic Chinatown neighbor hood. I really enjoyed walking through it, window shopping and eating.
Chinese New Year Parade let down

The day of the parade, we walked through Chinatown. Streets were blocked off for pedestrians only so that was nice. There were tents with vendors and free giveaways but the lines were very long and all in Chinese. It was fun to see the bustle of the crowds. Chinatown is full of kitschy stores with lots of stuff. I didn't like dumplings we had but my husband thought they were average. We visited the Tin How Temple that is tucked away in a side street. It is on the top floor. Very small and not what we expected. We can say we've been there. We left for lunch and a break before heading back to see the New Year Parade that evening. We were very excited about seeing it and had a good viewing spot near the beginning of the parade on Market Street. This was not the best parade we have seen. The timing was off so there were long gaps between floats or participants. There was a lot of repetition in performers, many martial arts, ribbons, and small dragons. Lots of spectators left before the end of the parade. We stayed because we wanted to see the 288 foot dragon. That was fun, with lots of firecrackers. Due to the poor timing of the parade we actually got to see the dragon for quite a while. It kept circling around the street waiting to advance. Perhaps in Chinatown proper it is more exciting to see, but for us it was quite a let down. But, we can say we were there and saw the dragon.
Show less
Worth a visit but parking is an issue

We went during the new year celbrations so it was very busy. Kind of place you feel you have to visit but dont be too dissapointed if you miss out. Its mainly shops selling there items. We did not eat, we wanted too but the cost of parking our car in the nearby car park would have cost more then the meal.
Show less
Went during the Chinese New Year celebration

Didn't really get to see much as there were hundreds of people down the street. There were street vendors and carnival rides for little kids. Would like to go back sometime when the place isn't so busy.
Bigger than NY, but w/o the charm
Admittedly I'm a New Yorker asnd biased, but while SF's Chinatown is bigger it doesn't have the character of NY's. It does have the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory though.
Steep streets. Small shops. Busy. Fun. Food.

Walked through China Town a few times. Lots of small shops, marketplace, fruits, vegetables and daily life. Nothing extraordinary just daily life, in it’s own simple beauty. Very steep streets walking from Harbour are up to Nob Hill. Try cable car ride if you can get onboard.
Hint: At Nob Hill find the CableCar Museum. Free. Fun to see. Active museum.
Show less

Not many cities can claim to have their own Chinatown within a city and San Francisco has one of the largest. It wonderful to stroll the streets and hear Chinese spoken, foreign signs on the builings, and authentic architecture. Experience the culture w/o having to travel through the music, the food and the festivities. Chinatown is one big celebration!
Show less
We loved Chinatown! It brought back memories from HK. Chinatown in SF is a good alternative to fill the Asian void...
A must tour in San Francisco

I wasn't interested in visiting the first time in San Francisco. This time we were with friends and it was a group decision. We had so much fun there. It was a total experience and it gave a real feel for the Asian culture. We spent the whole afternoon walking around and discovering new and interesting things. Please go on your next trip to San Francisco.
Show less

For a tourist attraction it is very authentic to Chinese culture. Lots of shops restaurants herb shops grocery stores with things I'm sure you've never seen. To be honest it's quite cheap compared to the rest of San Francisco. All the shops are competing with one another so you can haggle
Show less
China town is a lot of fun and has such a selection of delicious Dim Sum! Lots of hills in this area but worth the walk around this special area. Lots of choices of places to eat and shop.

This Chinatown is relatively small, but has all that you can expect from such a place: cheap Chinese food, cheap haircuts, small stores that sell almost anything that you can imagine, yoga/zen/meditation centers and noise.
It gets really crowded on Saturday where the sidewalks are covered with vendors.
It is located close to Little Italy and the Financial District and do not expect to find street parking anywhere.
Show less

I've lived in the SF Bay Area for almost my entire life and finally went to a Chinese New Year parade. I highly recommend it if you have a chance. It was a lot of fun! Lots of dragons, lion dancers, drummers and firecrackers.
Stop by Grant and Jackson get your fortune cookies. They will give yoo sample. For .50 you can get your picture with the lady.

A nice walk through Chinatown browsing in the shops is a lovely way to spend an afternoon. We were there just after Chinese New Year so there were plenty of decorations still up.

Some gorgeous things in the shops (and tat too!) But definitely worth a browse to find cheaper deals.
Show less
Largest Chinese Community in the United States

Relatively clean, this bustling community is the largest Chinese community in America. I recommend you walk through this are and sample the food, sights and smells. It's very interesting and loaded with shops that sell very unique Asian gifts.
Bustling place to stay. Great places to eat, really cheap. Buy cheap fruit. Transport easy to catch.
We walked a couple of blocks into the area and were disappointed that it was all purely tourist stuff. Junk for sale straight from, well, China!
I walked through Chinatown with a few friends one afternoon and we really enjoyed ourselves. We had lunch, then I picked up a lot of souvenirs for my daughters. (Fabric wallets, umbrellas...etc.)

The only part worth seeing are the entrance gates. We visited in the morning and looked through some stores. We took a few pictures and left. We didn't eat there, but the restaurants appear authentic.
An abundance of colour, smells and photo opportunities. Chinatown is such a vibrant place to be. There are vegan restaurants here, so everyone can find suitable eats.

This is one of my favorite areas to walk through in San Francisco. Very interesting architecture and shops, with restaurants serving amazing food. We've been here twice and in the Washington, D.C. Chinatown; I love San Francisco more!

Take a mini trip to Asia by visiting Chinatown! I loved browsing the shops for bargains and unique items. It is always a bustling area and you feel like you are immersed in an Asian country (with the exception of some menus and signs in English). So much great food, whether a sit-down upscale restaurant or a little dim sum joint. If you are there in February, do NOT miss the excitement of the Chinese New Year Parade!!
Show less

Super busy when you are visit here in the day time. There are all wholesalers right around here . Gift shop - dry food from China , Gold shop and anything.
Thais people call “Sampheng and Yaowarat “ China town is the old Market in Bangkok. So much fun all day and night time. PS. Take bus &taxi the best way to get here.
Show less
Not all Chinatowns are created equal
Great place to stroll through, some neat shops and interesting attractions. I’d visit this area again.

This is truly Chinatown, San Francisco has a huge Asian population and this is a reflection of that culture, this is not New York fake purse Chinatown. Very friendly and lots of shops. We did not take a walking tour, but I have friends that said it made their trip.
Show less
A lot of good stores and food. Nice spot to walk around, it is a lot like China towns in other cities but still fun. Good Vietnamese food

Finally was able to take my husband to Chinatown and it did not disappoint. First day of the Chinese New Year and there was an afternoon dragon walk which is always fun to see. The stores and helpfulness of others is bar non. Ask anyone and they will direct you to the next spot to be enjoyed.
Show less
Lots going on here. We were lucky enough to go on a Saturday where there was some kind of street festival going on. Very cool shops and really makes you feel like you’re not just in San Francisco

It’s Chinese New Year today and every where were lanterns The hustle of the city and the store fronts and the restaurants could easily take me a whole day of I had the time. Wish I spoke some Chinese as it would have been even more fun. The people were so friendly.
Show less

While we were in San Francisco we spent half a day in China Town. From the time you walk into the dragon entrance you defiantly walked into China. The structures are beautiful and there was defiantly a festive buzz in the air. We went in February and just a few days from Chinese New Year so there was all kinds of activities going on. I highly recommend finding the Fortune Cooke Factory and watch the older women make the cookies. You can sample and buy cookies here. As well we found this was the best place to buy Souvenirs for everyone. We stopped in a Little House of Dim Som - we got two plates of food (plates stacked full) and it only cost us $8.00. Walking around there were areas that were like a farmers market where you could buy fresh produce inexpensively and it looked good. You can also catch the Cable car from China Town down to Fisher mans Wharf.
Show less
Nothing amazing to see here. Lots of gift shops all selling the same things. We walked through and walked out again
Can’t get more authentic than tbis

Wow! What a neat place. Lots of great dining places and unique shopping. Be prepared to walk the hilly streets though. We liked it here. Compares to Toronto CA Chinatown. A must see experience while in San Francisco!
While the atmosphere in Chinatown can be rather unpleasant, the sensational food makes up for it. Disgusting pictures, smells, and loud sounds may be prevalent, but the food makes up for it by far!

I can’t say it enough! I just LOVE China town! I mean how can you not?! Fun cheap stuff, good food, good oriental food shopping for those hard to get and favorite items and beautiful views! The people in the stores tend to follow you around because of the theft problems they have, but not stealing anything so we don’t take offense to it. Something fun in every shop! Found my fav colorful fish chips that I get at our local Thai restaurant as a appetizer for only $1.25 a bag, fun candy for the kids that they have to make that look like sushi and doughnuts , pho making broth and noodles, toys for the kids and sooooo much more! Never can go wrong going to China town! Such an adventure and always find something new! Can’t wait to return!
Show less

We got lucky and happen to catch the Chinese New Year festival taking place in Chinatown. Lots of performances taking place and got to enjoy some dancing Dragons. I'm not sure what this place is like on any other given day but there was a lot of authentic Chinese restaurants and plenty of fresh fruits and vegetable stands. Cool architecture with a heavy Asian influence and hanging lanterns everywhere. It's definitely worth a visit if you enjoy Asian culture and cuisine.
Show less

This is a very touristy but fun spot to visit. We took one of the free tours provided by the library and learned a lot about the history of the area. We were surprised to stumble upon the local Tai Chi school training in the local park. This is a definite must visit spot when in San Francisco.
Show less
I love to visit Chinatown whenever I visit SF. It is not much changed in 40 years. I love the food and the atmosphere in this neighborhood. Dim sum is a must have experience each time we go.
Chinese markets, restaurants galore. Spend some time walking around here and have a bite to eat at one of the many restaurants.
walked through the food stalls it was crazy crazy busy full pavements of stalls ... though it busy you have to walk it
This area was great to stay in. It is relatively close to a lot of attractions throughout the city. Many Uber drivers in the area as well. Felt safe walking In the area at night.
Great place to mix with the local community

We spent an afternoon strolling through the streets of china town, its a great little neighborhood, the tourist to local ratio is perfect, we really got wrapped up in the local hustle and bustle, so much to see, so much delicious food to try and overall a great 2-3 hour walk.
Show less

Stopped by to check it out and was shocked at how busy it wasn't. I stopped by the archway. My biggest disappointment was how many people were trying to push their restaurant on you. It reminded me of Vegas but with food instead of clubs. Go for the experience and to say you were there!
Show less

This was a fun neighborhood to walk around. Lots of cute shops with Asian goods and just lots of pretty decor to enjoy on your stroll. There’s even a fortune cookie factory tucked away on an alley that is worth checking out if you can find it!!
Show less
It is definitely worth a walk through. Cheap gifts, people-watching, cool decor and authentic Chinese food.
Step into a Chinese community where the atmosphere never changes

Chinatown never seems to change over the past 40 years. Some shops and restaurants may change but the open market, restaurants, bakeries, and the Chinese language will always be there. You can find Chinese restaurants, Dim Sum, roasted ducks/chickens, and souvenirs. This is truly a "go to" place when in San Francisco. Parking is next to impossible on the street but at Portsmouth Square it is possible. Spend all of your time walking to experience Chinatown at its best.
Show less
There are real Chinese with real Chinese food. Everything is in Chinese on the boards for food but you can ask in English. Hint, read the numbers,they are usually prices.
With my daughter, son-in-law, and grandsons!

Got off our hop on hop off bus to visit this interesting area. This is where the Chinese live, it is not set up exclusively for tourists so don’t expect that! I love to see how other cultures live and I really enjoyed this experience. My grandsons aged 4 & 6 played at the playground near the Chinese Cultural Centre. I love how children have no prejudices they just interact as children. The streets are colourful and looking into the shops very interesting especially the ones specializing in herbal medicines. We watched fortune cookies be made. Grandson had a haircut, had lunch, bought some herbs to help with various conditions and took lots of photos! Be open minded and enjoy the experience! Observe and learn about others.
Show less
A great place to find a bargain, people watch and good Chinese food. Walk around, buy some souvenirs, listen to some street musicians, enjoy yourself.

San Francisco is a city foul of Asian immigrants and its Chinatown one of the biggest in USA.Every visitor must go there and admire Asian architecture and lifestyle.You may found something interesting at the numerous shops.

Chinatown is a different world. A fabulous walk with great places to eat and shops to look around in. The smells are different. The food is different. And the items is stored are from what I call the old China. It was the best part of San Fransico along with Coit Towner and Fisherman’s Wharf.
Show less
It is a little China but really not pretty or special. You can buy a lot of plastic stuff and it is dirty.
Unfortunately the streets are unkept, dirty, we didn’t feel safe. Maybe because so many people say so many good things we expected more...

If you want to experience Chinese culture without going to China then this is the place for you. Authentic restaurants abound, stop at one that looks good and enjoy food unlike any you’ve had. It’s just a fun place to spend some time.
was an lively place and a nice stop in our Hop on hop off bus
visited, shopped, had coffee and its a nice colorful experience, the gate is also very nice and easy to recognize the start of this neighborhood.

This is the best Chinatown I've ever been to. So many places to eat and drink and I loved experiencing the hustle and bustle of the residents up and down the streets buying their market produce. Great value and beautiful part of town!

As one of oldest communities in US a walk through Chinatown is a must. Lots of interesting shops, restaurants, massage parlours, community centre and spiritual places. You get a great feel of the mix of the community. I entered a store which was having a closing doen sale and was agressively pounced on to purchase something. This unnerved me, so made my exit. It did deter me from entering sny other shops. A great place to potter around and recommndd.
Show less
San Francisco Chinatown for ever changing

We parked in the garage located on Kearney St and upon exiting we were in a small plaza with elderly men playing cards games. We walked the main streets visited a number of shops. Mostly tourist ones. We ended up in Stockton Street where there are still assorted Chinese grocery stores with fresh vegetable and fruit. Fish markets too. We stopped by one of the bakery's and bought some items. Very good pork buns. We also made a stop at one of our favorite places for fortune cookies. The GoldenGateFortune cookie on Ross Alley. You can watch them make the cookies and how the paper fortune are inserted in to the cookies. I buy the flat cookies without the fortune. You can see that things have changed over the years, but still a nice area to tour.
Show less
China town is changing. Many places visited in years past are gone. Have spent a lot of time and money in China town but where did everybody go?
So many shops, so many restaurants. I love and hate China down. You can spend a whole days here and buy the cutest gifts. And you can’t go wrong with the food.
We spent most of our day here, shopping and walking around. Souvenirs of every kind. Great restaurants as well.
Only a few blocks full of stores with Chinese products and some restaurants. The fortune cookie store was worth it. I would return only for that. The food we ate was nothing exciting.

As someone who has travelled in China, i can say that many of the streets look a lot like the real China! Similar shops and smells!

It’s a nice walk through... also a nice place to get cheaper San Francisco souvenirs and great Chinese teas!

My highlight was the fortune cookie shop - you can see a lady making the cookies by hand!
Show less
Chinatown is a nice stroll and cultural experience

I was in San Francisco Chinatown this past Saturday(1/20/18). I think before going to Chinatown plan your trip right. Bring a jacket if planning to stay for the evening (winter time), bring comfortable walking shoes (some uphill and downhill walking), bring a carrying bags for food or merchandise purchases. think about parking, some parking garages or street parking. I parked in a garage on 170 Columbus Ave, San Francisco, CA 94133 after 3:00 pm $10.00 all day (Saturday) Just off Jackson st.. Nice starting point. easy to find after a long walk. Get a map. Always remember where you parked(important) it can be a maze of streets once you get into the market and business streets.Had a great time in the Dim Sum markets, merchandise stores and bakeries and restaurants and taking in the sites of cultural Chinatown (Plan on at least 3 hours or more). They are getting ready for Chinese new years. I took a cool picture with wall mural painting of Bruce Lee (see pics) on Jack Kerouac Alley and grant ave (Applemeister 1142 Grant Ave,). I am a huge Bruce Lee fan. I like the Dragon's gate Grant Ave and bush St. for the landmark picture. Some streets are well decorated with hanging lamps and buildings with Terra Cotta Soldier statues (see pics). Really had a great day. Start later in the day and stay for the evening night walk. Lots of the street vendors for vegetables and fruits are usually open in the morning and daylight hours. Restrooms in some dim sum markets and restaurants. If you buy something use the restroom. Your day activities depends on what you want to do. Hope this review helps and enjoy!! I Did.
Show less

Everywhere else in the city jacked the price up for tourist. Chinatown is still the place for great deals on shopping and just as good on food. For the real deal Chinese food, this is the only place to go.
Enter Chinatown via The Dragon's Gate

Chinatown is like most Chinatowns of the world and lots of fun to hunt down bargains, souvenirs and of course look for a moon cake and steamed pork bun. Escape into the stores and look for a bargain. Stop into Eastern Bakery about 4 blocks in on the right after the gates for a snack too.
Chinatown short stroll from Union Square area also.
Show less
I always go there. The stores are fun, the restaurants are good. You can find OK massage places and overall its a nice area to stroll and just discover.
Grant Avenue, Golden Gate Fortune cookies, Chinatown Alleys and more

Golden Gate fortune cookies 'factory' is tiny but worth a visit to watch them masking fortune cookies by pouring dough into shaped griddles which are then baked on a conveyor belt. the 'fortune' is then put inside the mould before it is folded. I didn't realise before this visit that fortune cookies don't come from China, they actually originated in the Japanese Tea garden in San Francisco in 1909. If you want to take a photo of the lady folding the cookies, then you need to pay a dollar.
After leaving the cookie factory we then ventured into Chinatown Alleys, full of old fashioned stores and small restaurants and the "Street of Painted Balconies" - just look upwards and you'll understand where the name comes from.
Show less
A tour guide will tell you take a trip to Chinatown. We liked the painted graffiti on the walls, with Bruce Lee featuring in a few places, lots of tourist shops, restaurants and a nice atmosphere.
Cool place, great bargains and amazing food. People were really nice too. Great art murals as well. Must go to when in San Fran.
Very commercialized. Could find the same thing in every store. Definitely catering to the tourist. Liked Vancouver Canada Chinatown better!
It is just an average chinatown. They have a ton of stores for souvenir shopping and very close to union square

The scenery was cool, but it seemed to me like a line of Chinese themed dollar stores. The one place we went to that my wife wanted clothes at, the lady followed us around like a vulture trying to get us to buy like 10 outfits for our daughter. Just a very underwhelming experience.
Show less

With every visit to San Francisco, we routinely walk through Chinatown and typically have a snack or a full meal. This trip was no different and, as in the past, enjoyed our time strolling up and down the many colorful streets. When all is said and done, our only complaint is the impossible number of restaurants to choose from. But this is part of the fun in that we try a new restaurant with each visit.
Show less
A lot of nice shops to browse through. If you are looking for souvenirs this has it all. Large range of prices. Restaurants to try out and tea houses.
The worst place i visited in SF

I was very excited to visit chinatown but totally regret doing so
The streets are not very clean with litter everywhere on the floor and smelly garbage all around.
Most of the restaurants there looked unclean and definitely wouldn't try eating in them
Nothing really interesting to see or do, just a lot of grocery stores so unless you would like to try out strange fruits/vegetables/spices then i wouldn't recommend wasting your time there
Show less
A great place to walk, buy and eat.

China Town is another gem of San Francisco. It is a great place to walk, shop and eat. Lots of great shops with unusual items. It pays to look around and compare prices. China Town is always busy with deliveries and quick walking locals doing their daily shopping. The markets with whole smoked chicken, squid, fish on ice and live fish and turtles are amazing. It is a great place to briefly step into a different cultural environment. Be respectful and you will have a great time.
Show less

Sorry, couldn't resist quoting the movie, but it's great! Chinatown is heaps of fun and there are lots of great places to eat, but the main reason for going here is the shopping. One of the very few reasonably priced places in San Francisco these days. If you're looking for your souvenir magnet for your fridge or a cheap t-shirt, this is the place to find it. Check it out on your visit.
Show less

Why you're walking through Chinatown you really think you're in China I really enjoyed the culture iJoy the atmosphere the music and the people it was simply amazing however there was plenty of walking to do and if Mobility is a problem this might not be for you. You cannot leave San Francisco without touring Chinatown after my experience there I think I would like to go to China.
Show less

San Francisco's Chinatown is quite like Beijing...in that it is pretty dirty and overwhelming. However it is a fun way for people who have not been to China to imagine themselves there. There are plenty of shops selling souveniers and some pretty good restaurants as well. We went at night and it was fun to see the street lanterns aglow. We ate at the Great Eastern Restaurant and were not disappointed.
Show less

This place was so so so cool! Make sure to check out the fresh fruit, veggie, and sea food markets they have after 10 am. There are murals in tons of alleys as well. Such a beautiful little city within the city!
No very different from other China Towns , worth if you haven’t visit one or eat good Chinese food

Very commercial, good places to shop Chinese things, a great variety , several choices for eating . Wear comfortable shoes to walk in the area. At night is not a lot of people walking around, so I think not very good for you to be alone
Show less

If you want Chinese cheap things then this is your place. I bought tea and chopsticks. You can find cloth, home decorations, tea, sweets, coffee, gold and many other things. The tea was delicious. The other things were cheap but I cannot comment on the quality.
Show less
Same as any China town around the world
Nothing special. Another dirty China town. If you have been to one anywhere in the world you don’t need to go here. There are too many beautiful up scale places in San Fran to waste your time there.
Great way to spend an afternoon!

We came here to do some shopping and have lunch. I found some great inexpensive souvenirs for my kids and our lunch was delicious. We tried some desserts from one of the bakeries and they were also very good. All in all, a fun afternoon. There’s lots to see here.
Show less
Stockton Street is where the action is

Similar to streets in Hong Kong and street markets in Beijing, Stockton street is where the locals to there shopping. Of Stockton and the East-West streets (Sacramento, Clay and others) are little alleys and parks to explore. Laundry hangs in the windows. Chinatown is still very poor and crowded.
Show less
You need to stay close together here. Lots of shady pan handlers. Not an area to bring small kids. Interesting how they hang their clothes out to dry from the windows. Didn't want to eat here.

If you haven't been to San Francisco's Chinatown, then you need to go. Now! What a neat place. Many different shops, souvenirs, food, grocery, tea, etc. When my stomach told me that I was hungry, I started looking for something that maybe just the locals went to. Boy, did I find just that! Although the name of the place evades my old memory, they're know for their specialty, a fish that is served to you alive. Yes, alive. No, I did not try it. I stuck with my old standbys, friend rice and some noodle dish. I had a ton of fun exploring Chinatown!
Show less
Busy making it hard to stay on sidewalk. Chinese ingedients all sold on street. Inexpensive Chinese items as well. Not my cup of tea but worth seeing

Hadn't been to San Francisco's Chinatown in 15 years. Walked through it going from Fishermans wharf to the Embarcadero.
Maybe it's my memory, but the district seemed less vibrant than before. We did get to eat at a good Chinese restaurant there, and enjoyed the walk through the district.
Show less
Worth seeing. Different to Sydney China town. Less restaurants.
Not better than china town in Sydney. Worth seeing but not better that SYDNEY chinatown. Lots of cheap buys.

We have spent a lot of time here on our latest visit to San Francisco. After completely missing it on our first visit we are making up for it this time. We have enjoyed the shopping for Asian antiques and treasures as well as some amazing food outlets. We are staying close by in Powell Street and enjoy the walk there and back. At present there are a lot of retailers having big sales or closing down so there are bargains everywhere. We only wish we were in a self catering apartment so we could buy some of the amazing fresh produce we have seen. The shopkeepers are so friendly and the atmosphere is great. So lovely to see the history and culture of the old San Francisco alive and well today.
Show less
Food a must, read other reviews !!!
Check out trip advisor for best food tips and you will not go wrong. Can’t remember where we went but trip advisor reviews proved to be so true! Shopping for tourist gifts was a lot of fun.

Just walk down Grant Street from the dragon gate on the Union Square side of Chinatown. Many fabulous restaurants and gift shops that will entertain young and old. One of the only places in California to get fireworks every day of the year. Many many interesting sites.
Show less
For the most part this area was flat which was a welcome change from SF's hills! Great little spot to grab cheap gifts and food.

Chinatown....a place where you will find fresh produce, fresh fish, hole in the wall street food, authentic asian cuisine and bakeries!

The smell of ancient spices and fish fill the air in this compacted neighborhood. If you see a line....stand in it! It’s obvious the locals know what’s good!
Show less

Unique trinkets, carving, jewelery, food, and fad items -- "head massager", anyone? -- plus the atmosphere of real Chinese marketplace serving a large Chinese population. Good reminder that lots of varied communities make a city.
A real eye opener. We loved our visit to China town and bought some of the obligatory tacky gifts. Picked up some gorgeous dim sum from a little take out place.
Lots of fun thing to buy and plenty of restaurants to eat at. Also some great tea shops you can sample wonderful teas.
Lots of shops with the same tourist stuff. Good restaurants everywhere although not exceptional. A couple hours of shopping was about all our group needed
Experience Asia at the heart of San Francisco

Spent an entire afternoon, leisurely strolling through the crowded street of China town. It was a short ride in cable car from union square. There are also several busses that plies this route. It was an interesting sight: streets are full of Asian grocery shops, wet markets, eateries, meat shops and shops selling Asian utility items. Whole place was fairly crowded, people, mostly Asian buying their groceries or food items. Though the name is China town, I could spot shops selling Thai and Philippine stuff as well. I had lunch at a Thai food restaurant, which was decent and authentic
Show less

My trip was really rich with events, flights, meetings, catch ups planned and ad hock. I didn’t manage to buy souvenirs and China town was the place solved the issue. I spend 10 minutes in some small store on the way to the airport at 8 am and was happy to complete SF with right feeling.
Show less
Worth a visit, but can be overrated

Tell someone you have been to San Francisco and they will ask you if you visited the Golden Gate Bridge, and then shortly after that they will ask about Chinatown. Chinatown is a unique, colorful, and loud place you should visit at least once. It's extremely touristy, so the streets will be crowded at most times of day. People are looking for some cheap goods and some Chinese experiences.

You'll find some interesting markets and shops. You have opportunities to try some things outside your comfort zone. It's a bustling place that you should go and try out. Walk around and see the sights and take the smells in. It's definitely worth a visit, but maybe not many return visits.
Show less
Regret to go there on the first day. Horrible Chinese food, streets are like wet fish market, gifts are old, dirty and badly kept, nothing to buy from there.

Chinatown San Francisco is huge! We walked around for about an hour and got to look at all the different things they sell and I’m pretty sure I would eat it. The seafood and fresh fruit and vegetables look delicious. We ate at New Asia for dim sum and it was pretty good. If you’re looking for something different to do and experience the Chinese culture you won’t be disappointed.
Show less
Largest Chinatown Outside of Asia; Gates Guarded by Chinese Guardian Lions

Worth venturing through the impressive Gates into Chinatown. Notice the Chinese Guardian Lions, also known as Foo Dogs, acting as noble sentries. Restaurants with traditional Chinese food; antique, jewelry and novelty shops abound. Definitely worth the journey, as this is the largest Chinatown outside of Asia, with over 100,000 residents.
Venture into Old St. Mary's, listed as a California Registered Historical Landmark. This was the first building erected as a cathedral in California. Originally built in 1853 by Chinese laborers with brick brought around Cape Horn, and granite mined in China, it was destroyed in the 1906 earthquake, and rebuilt in 1909, and presides high over The City. Chinatown has something to offer all ages.
Show less
A must see in San Francisco
Shops, dining, activities and incredible arts. There is something for everyone. Personalized fortune cookies down Ross Ave. What a great gift idea!!!
I didn’t like it very much. Variety is there but it’s not so much lively as I had expected. Nonetheless you can buy stuff for cheap from here.
This is the biggest China Town in the country!! Lots to see and eat and eat and eat! Cheap food and lots of options.
A true experience you do not want to miss. Great dinning from pennies on the dollar upwards to dine dinning. Lots of interesting shops. The merchants are very helpful and friendly .
Walk the length of Grant street from downtown to Northbeach. Definitely experience Sa Frans Chinatown and don’t be shy to bargain. Great place to pick up those last minute souvenirs.

Pretty much just like any other Chinatown around the world but on a larger scale.

Interesting to walk around, however it becomes quite repetitive as the stores don't differ too greatly from each other and all seem to sell similar items.

There's also plenty of street art adorning the walls and buildings, so it's a good photo op location.

We visited the Chinatown area of San Fran one mid week lunchtime.
To be honest we found it really run down, tired and unappealing.

Lots of businesses were closed up and the majority that were trading, pedaled cheap tack to the tourists.

Our aim was to have a good Chinese lunch but the restaurants that we saw along the main street from the Chinese entrance gate looked totally unappealing, dirty and nothing drew us in.

We did not last long and jumped a taxi and ate elsewhere.

Chinatown is fun but venture off grand and enjoy the real China town in Stockton. Buy you meat and fish here. Rabbits. Frogs. Live fish. Chicken hanging in the Windows. Fruit and vegetables - some you’ve never seen. A real delight.

Not bad, but most the stores are the same

We wanted to include Chinatown in our visit to San Francisco as my wife was looking forward to the shopping and culture. It is definitely worth a stop, but could probably be done in an hour or less
once you realize that 90% of the stores carry the exact same stuff.

There were some really neat high-end art/furniture stores that were great to walk through, but most of the other stores were carbon copies of one another.

I planned on stopping for some dim sum but we had eaten a huge breakfast so we skipped it, but there are plenty of places throughout Chinatown to stop for food if you choose - including a store that sells "dragon's beard" candy that was being made right there in the window.

A bit underwhelmed overall. I wouldn't put Chinatown near the top of my list if we were short on time, but it is worth a quick visit if you have a few days in SF.

The San Francisco Chinatown is one of the largest outside of Asia and one of the most densely populated areas in the USA.

We enjoyed strolling around this area and we found Chinatown quite by accident as we ventured a few blocks away from our hotel from the Union Square area upon arrival.

I have luved in Sanfrancisco most of my adult life and i have never seen more junk thats being sold in the stores on Grant ave in SF China town than any place on this Gods green earth than here . Probably no. 2 would be in Bangkok , Thailand on Sucomevet and Soy one in this 9 story shopping mall . When i came ti SF 47 years ago it always wasnt like this . It used to be quaint and a fun shopping experience to die for . I use to go into these stores on Grant ave to buy alot of fun and colorful stuff . lije Vases or furniture or jewelry . But now it has turned into a tourist trap of very expensive low and medium end junk all mass produced in China on some asembly line of slave laborers . Its really to bad . Becayse this makes a joke out of Sanfrancisco and its ambiance . China tiwn still has some great Chinese restaurants to eat at . I lice Chinese foods alot. . There is a place called Sam Wos on Grant and Washington street thats been there mire than 100 years that has really reasonable price food and flavorful too . I use to go there at 12 to 2 am to eat several of their plates of delectable chinese foods all for under $ 5.00 a plate . I loved it . This restaurant is a SF landmark . And its not a tourist trap either . Sanfrancisco has turned into a cheap Las Vagas. Rip off joint without the barkers . It didn't use to be this way .Urs a real crime that this gas happened here .Urs a reflection on how this city is being run . For real . Bye for now and happy traveling .

We visited from Chicago and have been to Chinatown there and in New York. This one had a great history component because of the migration of Chinese people to this city. Our guide brought us to a Buddhist temple and a dim sum restaurant. The classic Chinatown. It's all you've seen in the movies

It's Chinatown. Seen it on many movies. Here it is for real. Lanterns hung across the streets. Little restaurants everywhere. Many shops selling Asian style trinkets. Smell the incense as you walk around.
I visited this area because That's where the fabric shop is that I wanted to visit. There are lots of restaurants and shops. It's not a tourist area. It's a residential area.

Grant avenue is the main street of Chinatown. You should not miss the Chinatown Gate at Bush Street and Grant. There are many blocks of local markets, restaurants, bakeries and gift shops, The atmosphere is unique: experiencing the Chinese culture first hand with often musicians playing with oriental instruments. Try to find the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies down Ross Alley (they were invented in San Francisco). You will see how they are made and will be allowed to take all the pictures you want. However, you just leave 50 cents in the tip jar or buy some fortune cookies for a dollar or more..

I went to Chinatown with a group of my college friends! Although a lot of people compare this Chinatown to other Chinatowns or China itself, we felt this was more importantly a representation of Chinese Americans living in San Francisco. SFO's Chinatown can't be compared to China because the people that live there are not Chinese, they're Chinese American, and therefore the experiences are extremely different. We shouldn't pretend to be experts on cultures that we don't identify with, and should come into these spaces understanding that real people live and work here. Reviews on how this Chinatown failed to be authentic stem from an expectation of Chinatown as an extension of China, whereas Chinatowns were created as places of business as well as by patterns of oppression of Chinese people in America that kept these individuals in a particular space in the city. This in and of itself is a type of authenticity that shouldn't be overlooked.
P.S. We only rated the attraction because we had to in order to publish the review, but no one should be able to place a value on this space except for the people who live there.
Show less

San Francisco Chinatown is a neighborhood where people live, work, and play. It does not exist solely for tourist consumption and entertainment.

Many other reviews on this site demonstrate a complete lack of respect for the people of this neighborhood. This is not China, and it is also not other Chinatowns. While Chinatowns around the world may share some characteristics, they all have their own stories and histories (and forms of authenticity). Exoticizing this space using racist assumptions disregards these differences.

Tourists need to be especially considerate of the spaces that they enter and intentional about how they interact with the people there. Please watch your comments and be self-reflective about your thoughts while you're there.
Show less

A World Away from the Ordinary

Whenever visiting the SF area, I always try to walk through Chinatown. This time we started at the Dragon’s Gate entrance at Bush and Grant St. and took our photos with the standing bear and with the See No Evil, Speak No Evil monkeys. I love the exciting variety of somewhat chaotic colorful shops selling everything from clothing, furniture, silks, porcelain, jewelry, bronzes, herbs, baked goods, art work and much more, see photos. They are all so exotic, not like you are going to find at Walmart! This time we stopped in at the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory at 56 Ross Alley, off Jackson St. which is between Stockton and Grant. I’ve always wondered how they were made! There is so much more in Chinatown than you can find at home.
Did this review earn a “Thankful” vote?

Cool area, great food, great little markets but a lot less of a wow factor than I had expected. Other cities "Chinatowns" surpass SF's, even if their area is smaller.

I'm a 62 year old native San Franciscan...my wife is Chinese...I've been coming to Chinatown as long as I can remember...oh yeah, I lived in China for many years too!
Here's the deal...in Chinatown, Grant Ave. is for tourists. It's an amusing walk but the t-shirt shop clutter and photo-op gloss is not the "real" Chinatown. 1 block up, Stockton St. is where to go. Prepare yourself for authentic stores selling all manner of things "Chinese'...produce, traditional medicine, dim-sum, butchers, fish mongers etc. Always crowded, always bustling, always ALIVE! (just like China). Duck into any shop, gaze at products you may have never seen before...did I say "duck"? Yep, they're here too...hanging in the windows of the many tiny dim-sum eateries you'll find. Don't be shy, go in, sample, savor...and don't forget the bakeries...they're not just for fortune cookies!
For a "sit down" restaurant experience I would recommend a late morning visit to the "New Asia" on Pacific between Grant and Stockton. It's a cavernous old joint that serves a nice variety of traditional dim-sum from little carts that patrol the floor like some kind of wheeled Hong Kong siren...and, unlike many of the Hong Kong variety, these sirens are waitresses who speak English so don't hesitate to ask what's in those bamboo steamers. After you've stuffed yourself with all manner of dumplings, barbeque and what-not (braised chicken feet?...yes, please!) try the lobster noodles...a classic that's a terrific value as well...order it and look like a local! Bring a newspaper, sip the tea (jasmine?...you betcha!) take your time. The New Asia may not be the "best" dim-sum in SF but the experience is fun and very authentic...witness the clientele of long-time Chinatown residents in the tables around you...they know.
Now, get back out on the street to walk off your meal...prowl the lanes between Grant and Stockton...hear the traditional opera being rehearsed in upstair rooms...visit the Chinese American Museum...and begin to appreciate the families that live and work here...they're a big part of what makes San Francisco great...and they've been at it since the Gold Rush.

Its really authentic and you‘ll find some crazy stuff there. The streets are not very clean but they aren’t in china is well.
Vibrant, colorful neighborhood that is fun to explore

Bordered by Bush Street on the south, Broadway Street on the north, Stockton on the west and Kearney on the east, Chinatown is a warren of side streets and alleys filled with restaurants, shops, markets, bakeries and apartments. Walking is the only way to effectively tour the area and Grant Avenue is the central artery to explore. Numerous stores sell made in China souvenirs, from tea sets to textiles, furniture to jewelry, toys to Chinese herbs. The Asian markets with their poultry (complete with heads) hanging in the windows, the pungent smells of take away dishes and the unique selection of produce make a stroll a journey of discovery. Check out Old St. Mary's Cathedral and the colorful balconies onWaverly Place.
